column2: Mrs. Phillips stepped to the front door to meet the half dozen young people who were cheerily coming up the walk.
column3: mrs Phillips stepped to the front door to meet the half dozen young people who were cheerily coming up the walk.

column2: Cope, looking at the fallen cushions with an unseeing eye, remained within the drawing-room door to compose a further paragraph for the behoof of his correspondent in Wisconsin:
column3: Cope, looking at the fallen cushions with an unseeing eye, remained within the drawing room door to compose a further paragraph for the behoof of his correspondent in Wisconsin:

column2: They came on as thick as spatter. One played a few things on the violin.
column3: They came on as thick as spatter. One played a few things on the violin.

column2: Another set up her easel and painted a picture for us.
column3: Another set up her easel and painted a picture for us.

column2: A third wrote a poem and read it to us.
column3: A third wrote a poem and read it to us.

column2: And a few sophomores hung about in the background.
column3: And a few sophomores hung about in the background.

column2: The others--either engaged elsewhere or consciously unworthy--went away after a moment or two on the front steps.
column3: The others-either engaged elsewhere or consciously unworthy-went away after a moment or two on the front steps.

column2: Perhaps they did not feel "encouraged." And in fact Mrs. Phillips looked back toward Cope with the effect of communicating the idea that she had enough men for to-day.

column2: She even conveyed to him the notion that he had made the others superfluous.

column3: But-

column2: He met Hortense and Carolyn--with due stress laid on their respective patronymics--and he made an early acquaintance with Amy's violin.
column3: He met Hortense and Carolyn-with due stress laid on their respective patronymics-and he made an early acquaintance with Amy's violin.

The dear child," she said to Cope in a lower tone, "composed it herself and dedicated it to me."
column3: The dear child," she said to Cope in a lower tone, "composed it herself and dedicated it to me."

column2: The last little thing was a kind of "meditation," written very simply and performed quite seriously and unaffectedly.
column3: The last little thing was a kind of "meditation," written very simply and performed quite seriously and unaffectedly.

column2: And it gave, of course, a good chance for the arms.
column3: And it gave, of course, a good chance for the arms.

column2: And it inspired Carolyn too.
column3: And it inspired Carolyn too.

column2: She wrote a poem after hearing it."
column3: She wrote a poem after hearing it."

column2: A copy of verses, corrected Carolyn, with a modest catch in her breath.
column3: A copy of verses, corrected Carolyn, with a modest catch in her breath.

column2: She was a quiet, sedate girl, with brown eyes and hair.
column3: She was a quiet, sedate girl, with brown eyes and hair.

column2: Her eyes were shy, and her hair was plainly dressed.
column3: Her eyes were shy, and her hair was plainly dressed.

column2: Oh, you're so sweet, so old-fashioned! protested Mrs. Phillips, slightly rolling her eyes.

column2: Its title was read, formally, by the writer; and, quite as formally, the dedication which intervened between title and first stanza,--a dedication to "Medora Townsend Phillips."

column2: Of course, said Cope to himself.

column2: The poem was over, the patroness duly celebrated.

column2: Cope spatted a little too, but kept his eye on one of the walls.

column2: You're looking at my portrait! declared Mrs. Phillips, as the poetess sank deeper into the big chair.

column2: Hortense did it.

column3: It's getting almost too dark to see it, said his hostess, and suddenly pressed a button.

column2: He looked back again from the painter (who also had black hair and eyes) to her work.

column2: Isn't he the dear, comical chap! exclaimed Mrs. Phillips, with unction, glancing upward and backward at the girls.

column3: Meanwhile, how about a drop of tea? asked mrs Phillips suddenly. "Roddy"--to the sophomore-"if you will help clear that table...."

column2: The youth hastened to get into action.

column3: Phaon, a poor lad of nineteen, swept some pamphlets and paper cutters off the center table, and we all plunged into the ocean of Oolong-the best thing we do on this island...."

column2: He was lingering in a smiling abstractedness on his fancy, when--

column2: Bertram Cope! a voice suddenly said, "do you do nothing--nothing?"
column3: Bertram Cope! a voice suddenly said, "do you do nothing-nothing?"

column2: He suddenly came to.
column3: He suddenly came to.

column2: Perhaps he had really deserved his hostess' rebuke.
column3: Perhaps he had really deserved his hostess' rebuke.

column2: I mean, proceeded Mrs. Phillips, "can you do nothing whatever to entertain?"
column3: I mean, proceeded mrs Phillips, "can you do nothing whatever to entertain?"

He is quite prepared to wipe us all out.

column3: That's unfair, Cope protested.

column3: Will you sing before your tea, or after it?

column3: I'm ready to sing this instant,--during it, or before it.

column2: Very well.
column3: Very well.

column2: The room was now in dusk, save for the bulbs which made the portrait shine forth like a wayside shrine.
column3: The room was now in dusk, save for the bulbs which made the portrait shine forth like a wayside shrine.

column2: Roddy, the possible sophomore, helped a maid find places for the cups and saucers; and the three girls, still formed in a careful group about the sofa, silently waited.
column3: Roddy, the possible sophomore, helped a maid find places for the cups and saucers; and the three girls, still formed in a careful group about the sofa, silently waited.

I'll try not to."

column2: Possibly Cope gave too great heed to his hostess' caution; but it seemed as if a voice essentially promising had slipped through some teacher's none too competent hands, or--what was quite as serious--as if some temperamental brake were operating to prevent the complete expression of the singer's nature.

And finally comes Apollo." She reached over and murmured to Mrs. Phillips: "None too skillful on the lyre, and none too strong in the lungs...."

column2: Medora spoke up loudly and promptly.

column2: Do you know, I think I've heard you sing before.

column2: She looked up at him questioningly.
column3: She looked up at him questioningly.

column2: You don't like my poor girls, she said.
column3: You don't like my poor girls, she said.

column2: You don't find them clever; you don't find them interesting.
column3: You don't find them clever; you don't find them interesting.
